etymologies: early 17th century; earliest use found in Richard Preston (d. c1624). From classical Latin dēlēgant-, dēlēgāns, present participle of dēlēgāre delegate

definitions: A person or group of people who delegate authority, power, responsibilities, etc., to another person or group; later chiefly in contract law.
A person who delegates his or her debtor to a creditor in order to discharge a different debt.
